image.altText: A farmer in a blue shirt and jeans inspects a flooded paddock.

items.synopsis: Temporary supply shortages of vegetables and fruit are on the cards as individual farmers see many millions of dollars of produce and infrastructure wash away in Victoria's east.

title.children: Men rescued from rooftop of car in Victorian floodwaters, highway closed, as cost to farmers grows

image.altText: A blank Voice to Parliament ballot paper

items.synopsis: Dozens of constitutional and public law teachers from across the country have signed a letter in a bid to tackle "misunderstandings and misconceptions" about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Voice 'is not constitutionally risky', say 71 law professors in open letter to Australian public

image.altText: A man of East Asian background wearing medical scrubs. He is a wheelchair user

items.synopsis: Dr Dinesh Palipana says a ground crew member at Brisbane Airport ignored his carers and manoeuvred his wheelchair sharply, tipping him onto the ground.

title.children: Investigation launched after doctor and disability advocate tipped out of wheelchair at Brisbane Airport

image.altText: robert french

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Former chief justice defends Voice as legally safe, says Australians are better than 'don't know, vote No' slogan

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: French has clarified that there is no available  reading of the amendment which would require either Parliament or the  Executive Government to act upon representations made by The Voice. "They would have to be considered on their merits and in the light of other  legislative and administrative priorities," he said. He said there was also no available reading of the constitutional change which would  bind the Parliament to have regard to representations from The Voice about  a proposed law as a condition of its power to make such a law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No requirement for parliament to act upon representations made by the Voice

children.content: French has clarified that there is no available  reading of the amendment which would require either Parliament or the  Executive Government to act upon representations made by The Voice.
"They would have to be considered on their merits and in the light of other  legislative and administrative priorities," he said.

He said there was also no available reading of the constitutional change which would  bind the Parliament to have regard to representations from The Voice about  a proposed law as a condition of its power to make such a law.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: French says it would not matter whether Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were one race  or dozens of different races. "The Voice is not a race-based institution. "At federation there were hundreds of different  Aboriginal languages spoken across Australia," he said. "The unifying characteristic  which underpins the Voice is their history as our First Peoples."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The Voice is not a race-based institution'

children.content: French says it would not matter whether Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples were one race  or dozens of different races.
"The Voice is not a race-based institution
"At federation there were hundreds of different  Aboriginal languages spoken across Australia," he said.
"The unifying characteristic  which underpins the Voice is their history as our First Peoples."

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Watch Robert French's National Press Club address

image.altText: Director Nash Edgerton and Briggs on set for their skit at a pub.

items.synopsis: It starts with a conversation you might have had with a friend or family member over the last few months.

title.children: 'Just Google it': The Voice message that cut through and the Australian rapper that reached millions

image.altText: smoke glowing in the distance

items.synopsis: The Coologolite fire first sparked on Tuesday afternoon and has spread to 6,824 hectares, impacting areas of Cuttaggee, Barragga Bay, and The Murrah.

title.children: Two homes confirmed destroyed, another two damaged in Coolagolite bushfire

image.altText: A person holds onto some money.

items.synopsis: Newly appointed Fair Work Ombudsman Anna Booth vows to use yet-to-be-legislated criminal penalties against employers who deliberately underpay or rip off their workers.

title.children: New Fair Work Ombudsman vows to use criminal penalties to clamp down on wage theft

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a pink dress and heels poses laying back on an emerald green bed.

items.synopsis: Kylie Minogue has her highest US sales week for an album in almost 20 years, topping Billboard's Dance/Electronic Albums chart.

title.children: Viral hit Padam Padam returns Kylie Minogue to the top of US album charts

image.altText: A woman speaking into a microphone and gesturing on stage

items.synopsis: About 200 people gather at a No campaign event in Gawler, north of Adelaide, ahead of the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: No campaigners ramp up debate with community event in South Australia

image.altText: An elderly Aboriginal man wearing a wide-brimmed hat

items.synopsis: The ABC spoke to a number of First Nations people in Sydney and the regions to hear what the Voice means to them.

title.children: At 101, Bigambul man Wes has seen 'so many promises' broken. Now he's voting on the Voice

image.altText: A computer screen shows the Defence Health logo and options for insurance and contacting the company.

items.synopsis: One member is told just moments before a medical procedure that she will have to foot a $1,250 bill because she is not a financial member.

title.children: Hundreds of complaints after health insurer's IT glitch leaves customers with big medical bills and unpaid claims

image.altText: A kangaroo that looks like its playing an air guitar in a green field

items.synopsis: From a friendly-looking bear to an otter auditioning for Swan Lake, animals are full of surprises. Here is a selection of some of the shortlisted images for the 2023 Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards.

title.children: Air guitar roos and flossing beavers are among the finalists of the 2023 Comedy Wildlife Photo Awards

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australian shares are up slightly, after Wall Street closes down. Reserve Bank says small but rising share of homeowners in financial stress.  Follow live.

title.children: ASX up slightly, Reserve Bank says small but rising shares of households in financial stress

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the RBA's latest financial stability review is an important but grim reminder of the challenges facing households, the economy and the world in the midst of higher interest rates and inflation. But despite the global economic challenges, he says Australia is well placed to navigate a slower economic environment. He also acknowledged the current state of the economy with higher interest rates and inflation impacting thousands of households. Here's his statement in full: "The RBA report is an important reminder of the ongoing pressures facing the global financial system and the global economy," he said. " Higher interest rates, persistent inflation and the slowdown in China, particularly its struggling property sector, are weighing on global growth and will inevitably contribute to slower growth at home over the year ahead. "In the face of the challenges coming at us from around the world, Australia's resilient labour market and well-regulated financial system are among our strengths. "We know Australians are doing it tough and higher interest rates will continue to bite, particularly as more and more households come off lower fixed-rate mortgages. "In these difficult times, the Albanese Government is focused on making the budget more responsible and our economy more resilient, while rolling out billions of dollars of cost-of-living relief in a way that doesn't add to inflationary pressures .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial stability report an 'important reminder' of economic pressures, treasurer says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Whoa. Magellan Financial Group's losses have widened to more than 12% now (at 12:15pm AEDT). It's all because the fund manager reported a $4 billion drop in funds under management as of September, down to $35 billion. Investors clearly are not happy. PEXA Group has also been in the red, down by -5.5%. Macquarie has cut its price target for the digital property settlements platform because of its acquisition of UK-based Smoove. The brokerage says the deal lacks execution details and that Smoove is a loss making business. When it comes to the sectors: energy and healthcare are leading the losses (-0.5% and -0.3% respectively). The sectors doing well today are academic and education services (+0.5%), financials (+0.3%) and industrials (+0.3%). Let's take a look at the top movers : QBE Insurance (+2.3%) Iress Ltd (+2%) Telix Pharmaceuticals (+1.8%) Block Inc (+1.8%) Aristocrat Leisure (+1.7%) The bottom movers are: Magellan Financial Group (-12.7%) PEXA Group (-5.5%) IGO Ltd (-3.1%) Core Lithium (-2.7%) Neuren Pharmaceuticals (-2.5%)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Let's look at what's going on in markets this lunchtime

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has released its half-yearly financial stability review. Here are the key findings: It says higher inflation and interest rates continue to put pressure on household budgets, however, most borrowers are coping with the higher costs. Lower income households spend a larger share of their income on housing and essential items, therefore they are the most impacted by inflation. Home owners with variable rate mortgages have seen their payments increase by up to 50%, but the vast majority of borrowers have continued to service their debts. Borrowers who fixed their interest rates at record low rates (accounting for about 1/5 of housing credit) will roll of onto higher rates over the rest of this year (you know, the mortgage cliff!) however the bank says they don't appear to be at more risk than other borrowers, since they've benefited from an extended period of low rates. A small, but rising share of borrowers are in the early stages of financial stress. There's only been a slight deterioration in the banks' credit quality (because borrowers are mostly able to service their debts) And the banks are well placed to handle more funding and liquidity stress. Globally, China remains one of the biggest risks, because of its weakening property sector. However, the review says the direct links between Australia and China's financial systems are small.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank says borrowers are coping with higher interest rates

image.altText: the exterior of an office building with Australian Federal Police above the door

items.synopsis: A 19-year-old man is charged with child abuse offences after an international tip-off led police to raid his home.

title.children: Tip-off from US police leads to child abuse charges against Queensland man

image.altText: A woman closes her eyes while someone performs CPR practice on her

items.synopsis: People are less likely to give a woman CPR due to fears of hurting her or being accused of inappropriate touching. One Australian CPR provider is trying to change that by putting breasts on training mannequins.

title.children: 'My life is worth more than my boobs': Women are less likely than men to receive CPR in public

image.altText: Ecologist Dana Bergstrom kneels among rocks by the sea

items.synopsis: A prominent ecologist tells senators it's "too hard to do science" at the Australian Antarctic Division, revealing she quit due to advice from her dentist.

title.children: Stressed former Antarctic researcher had 'four cracked molars', quit on advice from her dentist

image.altText: A composite illustration of six images of students with small bits of paper covering their eyes and hiding their identities

items.synopsis: Tertiary students could soon have a new watchdog holding universities to account, but some warn that it must have strong powers.

title.children: Student ombudsman on the table as governments crack down on uni sexual assaults

image.altText: A woman on a boat looks back at a great white shark on the water, with a tuna in her lap

items.synopsis: Izzy Sesto's catch off the south-eastern coast of South Australia was a few kilos lighter after a great white shark took the bluefin tuna's tail then had a "play" with the boat's motors.

title.children: Fisher's 'epic' shark encounter as great white takes chunk out of massive tuna

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in a historic building.

items.synopsis: Analysis of more than 3,000 bank branches nationally suggests hundreds of regional locations are at risk of being closed, in addition to more than 1,600 closed around the country in the past six years.

title.children: Hundreds of regional bank branches are 'at risk' of closing, but 'there's no easy solution' to solve the problem

image.altText: an aerial shot of a fire inside a building

items.synopsis: An exclusion zone has been set up north of Newcastle due to the threat of an explosion inside an electrical plant.

title.children: Factories evacuated as overheated machine at Tomago electrical plant prompts explosion fears

image.altText: A rare Australian Painted Snipe standing in water, the bird is short and stocky, brown with a flash of white feathers.

items.synopsis: The discovery of an Australian painted-snipe at Lake Cargelligo in the Riverina has twitchers aflutter as sightings of the small bird are so rare that ornithologists don't even know what they sound like.

title.children: 'Holy grail' of water birds, the Australian painted-snipe, spotted in NSW

image.altText: A white dog looking through the cage door of its kennel.

items.synopsis: Certain dog breeds are banned from being imported to Australia, but residents are allowed to own them in Queensland under certain circumstances. The government wants to change that, but some experts think it's not the answer.

title.children: Queensland is cracking down on dangerous dogs, but some say banning them is complicated

image.altText: Soccer players in white and black stumble on the football pitch.

items.synopsis: An Australian A-League team played a football match in war-torn Myanmar against the government's official travel advice, with some observers calling the move dangerous.

title.children: Furore over Australian soccer team's match in war-torn Myanmar during AFC Cup

image.altText: A close-up shows a woman placing a green nut into her mouth

items.synopsis: In PNG's Manus province, dozens of locals have gone missing in treacherous journeys across the seas in search of the addictive betel nut. Some of them drown, but others meet their ends at the hands of other traders, or pirates.

title.children: 'They're killing people at sea': The lucrative PNG trade that gave rise to pirates

image.altText: Male rescue workers working near the site of a badly damaged building.Trees in the background.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian officials say a Russian attack on a village in the north-east of the country has killed 51 people, including a child.

title.children: 'No military targets': Russian missile attack kills more than 50 civilians in one of the deadliest strikes in Ukraine war

image.altText: Plants, farmers and dish

items.synopsis: Farmers in Western Australia are turning salty wastelands into pillows of gourmet greens — and they're now in high demand in Australia's best restaurants.

title.children: These salty plants grow in a farming wasteland and could feed the world's growing population

image.altText: Marcus Stoinis poses for a photo in New York

items.synopsis: Australian all-rounder Marcus Stoinis reveals the moment he realised an impromptu photo shoot on the streets of New York was about to go viral.

title.children: 'Oh no. What have I done?': The impromptu NYC photo shoot that introduced an Aussie cricketer to a million new fans

image.altText: Social media icons on a phone screen.

items.synopsis: The European Union is considering a proposal which would force tech companies to make their apps less addictive.

title.children: EU considering proposal to make phone apps less addictive. These are the features that could be restricted

image.altText: A completely empty chamber of the House of Representatives with not a single person in the green seats.

items.synopsis: Conjecture continues to circulate online regarding what can be changed about the Voice through legislation in the event of a successful referendum. RMIT ABC Fact Check spoke to experts to clear it up.

title.children: CheckMate: Would a second referendum be needed to make changes to the Voice?

image.altText: Protest at busy roundabout, Martlesham, Suffolk, England, UK Climate Emergency is a scam, no to cashless society.

items.synopsis: The United States has a long history with conspiracy theories, and Australia isn't immune to them either.

title.children: Lizard people, the Illuminati and the CIA: How conspiracy theories thrive on fear

image.altText: A picture of a snowy peak.

items.synopsis: Western Europe's highest peak has lost more than two metres in two years and shrunk to its lowest height since precise measurements started 22 years ago, French researchers say.

title.children: Europe's Mont Blanc mountain has shrunk to its lowest height in 22 years

image.altText: An illustration of five people standing in a line

items.synopsis: We asked ABC readers what they wanted to know about the voice referendum and received thousands of responses. Here are the answers to some of the most frequently asked questions.

title.children: Voice to Parliament explained: You had the most to ask about purpose, voting, bodies, structure. Here are the answers
